name: Vancomycin + Gentamicin — Acute Kidney Injury
description: 68-year-old male admitted to ICU with sepsis. Started on Vancomycin and Gentamicin for empiric broad-spectrum coverage. Baseline renal function normal but deteriorates over 40 hours as nephrotoxic drugs accumulate.

steps.narrative: Admission. Labs normal. Static CDS fires 5 alerts for Vancomycin-Gentamicin interaction. Context-aware system: silent — organ function supports clearance of both drugs.
8 hours post-admission. Minimal change in renal markers. Static system fires again on med reconciliation. Context-aware: still silent.
Creatinine creeping up. GFR declining. Context-aware system notes informational trend — 'Renal function trending down, monitoring recommended.' Not an interruption.
Significant renal decline. Creatinine 70% above baseline. Context-aware system elevates to WARNING — displayed as a non-interruptive card in the patient chart. Clinician can review at next rounding.

CRITICAL. Creatinine 2.4× baseline. GFR dropped 60%. Both drugs accumulating beyond therapeutic range. Context-aware system fires CRITICAL alert with full intervention card: mechanism, projected trajectory, and specific recommendation to switch Gentamicin to Ceftriaxone.

Without intervention: severe AKI. GFR <30 indicates Stage 3 AKI. Hyperkalemia risk (K+ 5.8). This timeline shows what happens when static alerts are overridden and context-aware alerts are not available.
